rules.title: Exploit Public-Facing Java Application (WebSphere/WebLogic) Execution
rules.description: Detect execution of Java processes that contain indicators of known CVE exploits targeting IBM WebSphere or Oracle WebLogic servers.

detection.condition: selection_java_weblogic or selection_java_websphere or selection_cve_2017_1000486 or selection_cve_2015_7450 or selection_cve_2010_5326 or selection_edb_24963

falsepositives: Developers or administrators running WebSphere/WebLogic locally for testing
Security teams executing proof‑of‑concept exploit scripts in a lab environment
Automated build or CI pipelines that invoke java.exe with WebLogic/WebSphere related arguments

attacks.description: Basic check: sends a simple HTTP request to the WebLogic CoordinatorPortType endpoint to verify if the service is reachable and potentially vulnerable.
attacks.expected_behavior: The server returns an HTTP response (e.g., 200 or error). A vulnerable server may return a deserialization error indicating the endpoint is exploitable.

attacks.description: Intermediate exploit: creates a dummy binary payload file and POSTs it to the vulnerable WebLogic endpoint, mimicking a serialized Java object upload.
attacks.expected_behavior: The server processes the binary data; if vulnerable, it may attempt deserialization and respond with an error or execute embedded commands.

attacks.description: Advanced exploit simulation: starts a netcat listener on port 4444 in the background and sends a crafted serialized object (placeholder) to the vulnerable endpoint to simulate a reverse shell trigger.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the target is vulnerable and processes the malicious.ser payload, it will initiate a reverse connection to the listening netcat session, resulting in a shell on the attacker machine.

attacks.description: Create a test file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file in the user's TEMP directory with benign content.

attacks.description: Download a file using certutil executed via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a URL using certutil, initiated through PowerShell.

attacks.description: Create scheduled task via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a scheduled task named 'TestTask' to execute a benign command, requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: Basic command to write the current date to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named date.txt will be created in the temp directory with the current date

attacks.description: Intermediate command to compress the date.txt file using Compress-Archive
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named date.zip will be created in the temp directory with the date.txt file inside

attacks.description: Advanced command to clean up the temp directory by removing the date.txt and date.zip files
attacks.expected_behavior: The date.txt and date.zip files will be removed from the temp directory

attacks.description: Attempt to login using default credentials for the 'sysadmin' user
attacks.expected_behavior: Login attempt using default credentials

attacks.description: List the commands that the 'sysadmin' user can run with sudo
attacks.expected_behavior: List sudo permissions for the 'sysadmin' user

attacks.description: Switch to the 'sysadmin' user using the default password
attacks.expected_behavior: Switch user to 'sysadmin'

attacks.description: Creates a simple ASP web shell in the temp directory using cmd.exe.

attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to connect to a target IP via SSH and execute an interactive bash shell, simulating exploitation of a remote service

attacks.description: Basic exploitation attempt of a remote telnet service
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to establish a telnet connection to a target IP on the default telnet port, simulating an exploitation attempt of a remote service

attacks.description: Creates an uncompressed tar archive of two test files in /tmp, simulating collection of targeted data.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named collected_data.tar appears in /tmp containing the two specified test files.

attacks.description: Compresses all .log files from /var/log into a gzip‑compressed tarball, excluding any existing .gz files.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed archive /tmp/collected_logs.tar.gz is created containing the .log files from /var/log, omitting any .gz files.

attacks.description: Finds all configuration files under /etc and streams them into a gzip‑compressed tar archive, excluding backup files.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed archive /tmp/etc_conf_archive.tar.gz is produced containing all *.conf files from /etc, with any *.bak files excluded.

attacks.description: Basic directory listing of user's Documents folder
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays file/folder list in Documents directory including hidden/system items

attacks.description: Intermediate ASCII tree structure of Public Documents
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows folder hierarchy with files in ASCII format for Public Documents

attacks.description: Advanced multi-location directory discovery with PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Recursively lists directories (2 levels deep) from system temp, program data, and user profile, saving results to TEMP\discovery.txt

attacks.description: List files and directories in /etc/ with detailed information
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories in /etc/ with detailed information

attacks.description: Find all directories in /home and print their paths
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the paths of all directories in /home

attacks.description: List files and directories in /var/log/
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories in /var/log/

attacks.description: Modifies the current boot entry to reference a test file in TEMP
attacks.expected_behavior: Changes the boot loader path to a benign test file, simulating modification of boot components for fraudulent transactions

attacks.description: Updates the Master Boot Record (MBR) with NT60 boot code
attacks.expected_behavior: Rewrites the MBR to demonstrate boot sector modification capability without payload execution

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\test.bin -Value 'TestBootCode' -Force; $guid = (bcdedit /create /d 'Test Boot' /application bootsector | Select-String '{').Line.Split('{}')[1]; bcdedit /set {$guid} device partition=C:; bcdedit /set {$guid} path \"$env:TEMP\test.bin\""
attacks.description: Creates test boot file and registers new malicious boot entry
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a benign test file, generates new boot entry, and configures it to execute from TEMP directory during boot sequence

attacks.description: Creates a test file in the boot directory to simulate modifying system components before boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the /boot directory containing the specified test string.

attacks.description: Backs up the GRUB configuration and then overwrites it with a test string, simulating a modification that could affect boot behavior.
attacks.expected_behavior: The original GRUB configuration will be backed up, and a new GRUB configuration file will be created with the test string, potentially altering boot settings.

attacks.description: Creates a new directory and file under /etc/ld.so.conf.d to simulate adding a custom library path, which could be used to load malicious libraries early in the boot process.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new directory and configuration file will be created under /etc/ld.so.conf.d, which could influence dynamic linker behavior.

attacks.description: Start the Remote Desktop Service to enable remote access
attacks.expected_behavior: Remote Desktop Service starts, allowing remote connections

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to start a remote desktop connection to localhost
attacks.expected_behavior: Remote Desktop Connection attempts to connect to localhost

attacks.description: Configure the Remote Registry service to start automatically
attacks.expected_behavior: Remote Registry service is set to start automatically on boot

attacks.description: Establish a basic SSH connection to a remote host
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a secure shell connection to the specified remote host

attacks.description: Sets up a netcat listener that executes /bin/bash upon connection, allowing remote access
attacks.expected_behavior: Listens on port 8080 and executes /bin/bash when a connection is established, potentially allowing unauthorized access

attacks.description: Generates SSH keys and copies the public key to a remote host for password-less login
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates SSH keys locally and copies the public key to the remote host, enabling key-based authentication

attacks.description: Uses a stolen SSH private key file to authenticate to a remote host and execute 'whoami' to verify the logged-in user.
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH client authenticates using the provided key and prints the username of the remote account (e.g., 'user').

attacks.description: Loads the stolen SSH private key into ssh-agent, then uses the agent to authenticate to the remote host and run 'id' to display user information.
attacks.expected_behavior: ssh-agent starts, the key is added, and the subsequent SSH connection succeeds without specifying the key, printing UID/GID info.

attacks.description: Copies a malicious public SSH key into root's authorized_keys file and secures its permissions, enabling future root SSH logins using the corresponding private key.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the attacker possesses the matching private key, they can SSH into the machine as root. The command updates the authorized_keys file and sets restrictive permissions.

attacks.description: Adds a registry entry to run a command at user login using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a persistent registry key under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run that executes 'cmd.exe /c echo Hello' at user logon

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { New-Item -Path 'HKCU:\Software\Test' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-ItemProperty -Path 'HKCU:\Software\Test' -Name 'Backdoor' -Value 'cmd.exe /c echo test' } catch { exit 1 }"
attacks.description: Creates a test registry key and sets a value using PowerShell with error handling
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a registry key at HKCU\Software\Test and sets a string value named 'Backdoor' with a test command. Uses error handling to continue on failure.

attacks.description: Executes a base64-encoded PowerShell command that modifies the registry using Set-ItemProperty
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs a PowerShell command that adds a registry entry under HKCU for persistence. The command uses encoding to simulate obfuscation, but performs the same benign action as the previous examples.

attacks.description: Appends a malicious path to the user's bashrc file for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious path is added to the user's bashrc file, allowing for potential execution of malicious commands upon user login.

attacks.description: Modifies the system-wide bashrc file to alias the ls command, demonstrating registry modification for persistence with admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The ls command is aliased to show all files including hidden ones, potentially leading to information disclosure or execution of malicious files.

attacks.description: Modifies a system configuration file to change a setting, demonstrating persistence without requiring admin privileges for the specific file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The color setting in the terminal is changed, which is a benign modification but demonstrates the ability to persistently modify system settings.

attacks.description: Basic command to simulate searching for common SQL-related user accounts using built-in net and findstr commands.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists user accounts from 'net user' output and filters for lines containing 'sa' or 'admin'. No actual passwords are retrieved. Runs quickly and safely.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-CimInstance -ClassName Win32_Group -Filter 'LocalAccount = True' | Where-Object { $_.Name -match 'Administrators|SQL' } | Select-Object Name, SID"
attacks.description: Intermediate command using PowerShell to query local groups related to SQL or administrators via WMI/CIM.
attacks.expected_behavior: Queries local Windows groups using CIM, filtering for those with 'Administrators' or 'SQL' in the name. Outputs group name and SID. Requires admin for full visibility into group memberships.

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscated command simulating delayed execution often seen in evasion; base64 decodes to 'Start-Sleep -Seconds 5' as a benign placeholder for credential harvesting.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and executes a harmless delay command (5-second sleep). Used to simulate obfuscated attack chains without performing harmful actions. Base64 is UTF-16LE encoded as required.

attacks.description: Retrieve information about all groups on the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all groups on the system, which can be used to discover permission groups.

attacks.description: Filter group information to find specific groups based on a keyword.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays groups containing the specified keyword, demonstrating an intermediate approach to discovering permission groups.

attacks.description: Find the groups a specific user belongs to and filter by a keyword.
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows the groups the user is a member of, filtered by the keyword, representing an advanced approach to permission group discovery.

attacks.description: Appends a harmless touch command to /etc/rc.local so a file is created on each system boot, demonstrating modification of a system startup script.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next reboot, /etc/rc.local will execute and create /tmp/persistence_test, confirming the persistence entry was added.

attacks.command:
printf '[Unit]
Description=Test Persistence Service
After=network.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/touch /tmp/persistence_service
Type=oneshot

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
' > /etc/systemd/system/test-persist.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable test-persist.service && systemctl start test-persist.service
attacks.description: Creates a new systemd unit file that runs a harmless touch command, reloads the daemon, enables the service for future boots, and starts it immediately.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service file is written, systemd is reloaded, the service is enabled, and /tmp/persistence_service is created both now and on subsequent boots.

attacks.description: Adds a root crontab entry that executes a touch command at reboot, providing persistence via the cron scheduler.
attacks.expected_behavior: The crontab now contains an @reboot line; on the next system start, /tmp/persistence_cron will be created, confirming the cron‑based persistence.

attacks.description: Basic command to retrieve kernel name, version, and architecture.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a single line containing the kernel name, hostname, kernel release, version, machine hardware name, processor, hardware platform, and operating system.

attacks.description: Intermediate command that displays OS distribution details and detailed CPU architecture information.
attacks.expected_behavior: First prints key/value pairs describing the operating system (NAME, VERSION, ID, etc.). Then prints a formatted table with CPU model, cores, threads, architecture, and other hardware characteristics.

attacks.description: Advanced command that extracts DMI/SMBIOS system information such as manufacturer, product name, version, and serial number.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a block of text containing fields like Manufacturer, Product Name, Version, Serial Number, UUID, and Wake-up Type for the system hardware.

attacks.description: Basic DLL loading via rundll32 simulating process injection
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches shell32.dll's SHCreateLocalServerRunDll function in a new process, demonstrating DLL execution.

attacks.description: Modifies AppInit_DLLs registry key to load user32.dll into processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets AppInit_DLLs to load user32.dll (benign) into processes post-reboot, simulating DLL injection setup.

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= "rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\user32.dll,MessageBoxA" start= auto && sc start TestService
attacks.description: Service-based DLL injection via sc.exe (admin required)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates/start a service running user32.dll's MessageBoxA via rundll32, demonstrating code execution in SYSTEM context.

attacks.description: Injects code into a running Firefox process using gdb, allocating memory and writing to it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to inject code into a running process, demonstrating process injection capabilities without causing permanent damage.

attacks.description: Compiles a simple C program that executes a shell command, demonstrating code injection through compilation and execution of a binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: The compiled program executes a shell command, showcasing the ability to inject and execute arbitrary code.

attacks.description: Attaches to a running Firefox process using ptrace, demonstrating the capability to intercept and manipulate process operations.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attaches to the process, allowing for potential code injection or manipulation, but requires elevated privileges and poses a higher risk.

attacks.description: Encode and decode a file using certutil to obfuscate content
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes a sample text file into Base64 and decodes it back, demonstrating file content obfuscation using native Windows utilities

attacks.description: Execute base64-encoded PowerShell command to write a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs an obfuscated PowerShell command that creates a text file in TEMP directory, demonstrating command-line obfuscation techniques

attacks.description: Hide data in NTFS alternate data stream and extract it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates and reads from an alternate data stream, demonstrating file structure obfuscation through NTFS features

attacks.description: Create a text file, then encode its contents using base64
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file is created, and its contents are encoded and saved to another file

attacks.description: Create an empty file, compress it, and then rename it to hide its original purpose
attacks.expected_behavior: An empty file is created, compressed, and then renamed to obscure its original purpose

attacks.description: Create a text file with a test string, then encrypt it using AES-256-CBC
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file is created, and its contents are encrypted and saved to another file

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: streams the contents of /etc/passwd to the attacker over a netcat TCP connection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file /etc/passwd is read and its raw bytes are sent to attacker.example.com on port 4444; the command exits after the transfer or timeout.

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: archives the /var/log directory, sends the compressed archive via netcat, then cleans up the temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/logs.tar.gz containing logs, streams the archive to the attacker, and finally deletes the temporary archive.

attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: opens a TCP socket on file descriptor 3, base64‑encodes /etc/shadow and writes it to the socket, then closes the descriptor, reusing an existing C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a TCP connection to attacker.example.com:5555, streams the base64‑encoded contents of /etc/shadow over that connection, and cleanly closes the socket.

attacks.description: Creates a .reg file in /tmp that defines a Run key for the current user pointing to a benign script.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file /tmp/malicious_run.reg is written containing the registry entry; no actual registry is modified.

attacks.description: Creates a .reg file and imports it into the Wine user registry, simulating a per‑user Run key persistence entry.
attacks.expected_behavior: The .reg file is written and then imported into the Wine registry, creating a Run key for the current Wine user. No changes are made to the host system's registry.
